org.chronos.chronograph.internal.impl.structure.record

Class EdgeRecord

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.chronos.chronograph.internal.impl.structure.record.EdgeRecord
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    ElementRecord

    @PersistentClass(value="kryo")
 @ChronosExternalizable(converterClass=EdgeRecordConverter.class)
public final class EdgeRecord
extends java.lang.Object
implements ElementRecord
    An EdgeRecord is the immutable data core of an edge that has been persisted to the database.

    This is the class that will actually get serialized as the value in ChronoDBTransaction.put(String, Object).

    It is crucial that all instances of this class are to be treated as immutable after their creation, as these instances are potentially shared among threads due to caching mechanisms.

    The ChronoEdgeImpl implementation which typically wraps an EdgeRecord is mutable and contains the transient (i.e. not yet persisted) state of the edge that is specific for the transaction at hand. Upon calling ChronoGraphTransaction.commit(), the transient state in ChronoEdgeImpl will be written into a new EdgeRecord and persisted to the database with a new timestamp (but the same vertex id), provided that the edge has indeed been modified by the user.

    Note that an EdgeRecord only contains the id of one end of the edge. The reason is that the edge will always be serialized embedded in an VertexRecord, and the vertex record keeps track of the incoming and outgoing edges. Therefore, one 'end' of the edge is always given by the containment structure.
